Taxonomic information

Matilda Stevenson

2021-06-30

Source: vignettes/taxonomic_information.Rmd
taxonomic_information.Rmd

galah provides multiple ways of getting taxonomic information. This vignette clarifies how to make the most of the functions for various use cases.

library(galah)
ala_config(email = "ala4r@ala.org.au", caching = FALSE)

Taxonomic filtering

All the ala_ functions in galah (ala_occurrences(), ala_counts(), ala_media() and ala_species()) optionally take a taxonomic filtering argument, taxa, which is a vector or data.frame of taxonomic ids. To construct the taxa filter argument, select_taxa can be used. select_taxa looks up a taxonomic name or identifier and returns information about the ALA taxon which matches.

Species information

Species-level information is most easily retrieved using ala_species(). As mentioned above, ala_species() can take a taxonomic filter argument as constructed by select_taxa().

acacia_sp <- ala_species(taxa = select_taxa("Acacia"))
## Assuming that query term(s) provided are scientific or common names

Intermediate species information

By default, ALA web services don’t provide information on intermediate taxon ranks e.g suborder, superfamily. select_taxa and ala_species can provide this information if requested, by passing all_ranks=TRUE to the function.

Example: building a taxonomic tree

To build a data.frame of taxonomic tree information for Myrtaceae, we can use select_taxa() and ala_species(). First, we use select_taxa to create the taxonomic filter.

taxa <- select_taxa("Myrtaceae")
## Assuming that query term(s) provided are scientific or common names
taxa
##   search_term scientific_name scientific_name_authorship
## 1   Myrtaceae       Myrtaceae                      Juss.
##                                     taxon_concept_id   rank match_type kingdom
## 1 https://id.biodiversity.org.au/taxon/apni/51313356 family exactMatch Plantae
##       phylum         class    order    family      vernacular_name  issues
## 1 Charophyta Equisetopsida Myrtales Myrtaceae myrtle family (part) noIssue

Then we pass this information to ala_species()

species <- ala_species(taxa = taxa)

And display the information in a tree:

library(collapsibleTree)
collapsibleTree(species,
                hierarchy = c("family", "genus", "species_name"),
                root = "Myrtaceae",
                width = 1000)

Lower taxonomic information

Issues:

  • How to get intermediate information
  • How to interact with taxize
library(galah)
ala_config(atlas = "Australia", email = "matilda.stevenson@csiro.au")

Intermediate rank information

select_taxa doesn’t provide information about intermediate rank due to a bug in the name-matching service. Need to make a separate call to the species web services to get this information (and this works for any taxonomic level).

library(jsonlite)
# use select_taxa to get id
select_taxa("Anas anas")
## Assuming that query term(s) provided are scientific or common names
##   search_term scientific_name scientific_name_authorship
## 1   Anas anas            Anas             Linnaeus, 1758
##                                                              taxon_concept_id
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:ca7b0c33-4059-4324-ae5b-813630bd61c0
##    rank  match_type  kingdom   phylum class        order   family genus  issues
## 1 genus higherMatch Animalia Chordata  Aves Anseriformes Anatidae  Anas noIssue
id <- select_taxa("Anas anas")$taxon_concept_id
## Assuming that query term(s) provided are scientific or common names
# pass id to BIE in a separate query
taxa <- fromJSON(paste0("https://bie-ws.ala.org.au/ws/species/", id))
# this returns lots of stuff, including the rank information
classification <- data.frame(taxa$classification)
classification
##    kingdom
## 1 ANIMALIA
##                                                                   kingdomGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:4647863b-760d-4b59-aaa1-502c8cdf8d3c
##     phylum
## 1 CHORDATA
##                                                                    phylumGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:065f1da4-53cd-40b8-a396-80fa5c74dedd
##   class
## 1  AVES
##                                                                     classGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:5ed80139-31bb-48a8-9f57-42d8015dacbb
##          order
## 1 ANSERIFORMES
##                                                                     orderGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:b8bb0d5b-27f3-4cd9-a9e6-4806dfadb5aa
##     family
## 1 ANATIDAE
##                                                                    familyGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:61e10186-a256-428a-baf9-331012e4cf29
##   subfamily
## 1  Anatinae
##                                                                 subfamilyGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:d556baf4-5def-44f2-863a-8504a49c87c9
##   scientificName
## 1           Anas
##                                                                          guid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:ca7b0c33-4059-4324-ae5b-813630bd61c0
##   genus
## 1  Anas
##                                                                     genusGuid
## 1 urn:lsid:biodiversity.org.au:afd.taxon:ca7b0c33-4059-4324-ae5b-813630bd61c0

How best to help a user get this information? - Additional rank-specific argument e.g. ranks = all

select_taxa("Vombatus ursinus", ranks = c("family", "order", "suborder"))
select_taxa("Vombatus ursinus", ranks = "all")
  • Additional columns argument- could add count info to this?
select_taxa("Vombatus ursinus", columns = select_columns(group = "taxon_ranks", "count")
  • Something else?

Intermediate ranks for lots of species

# ala_species is easier to use for species information if > 1 rank below
# is required
mammals <- ala_species(taxa = select_taxa("Mammalia"))
all_mammal_info <- data.table::rbindlist(lapply(mammals$species, function(id) {
  taxa <- fromJSON(paste0("https://bie-ws.ala.org.au/ws/species/", id))
  row <- data.frame(taxa$classification)
  row$count <- ala_counts(taxa = select_taxa(id))
  row
}), fill = TRUE)

head(all_mammal_info)

Plot taxnomic info

library(collapsibleTree)
library(dplyr)
all_mammal_info <- all_mammal_info %>%
  mutate(final = paste0(.$scientificName, " (", .$count, ")"))
collapsibleTree(all_mammal_info,
                hierarchy = c("order", "suborder", "superfamily", "family",
                              "subfamily", "genus", "subgenus"),
                root = "Mammalia",
                width = 1000)

Taxize

library(taxize)
# Taxize queries multiple DBs e.g. NBN, Sweden
# It returns an id with lots of attributes, and lots of options, but can just
# pick the top one
id <- get_nbnid("Sciurus vulgaris", rows = 1)
id
# can then get more classification information
classification(id, db = "nbn")

# there are downstream, upstream and children functions for some databases e.g. GBIF
id <- get_gbifid("Homo")
downstream(id, downto = "species")

Thoughts:

  • The upstream and downstream functions in taxize are nice but only work for some databases; and there are no APIs supporting these functions, they just do some hacking in the background.
  • Taxize doesn’t import rgbif because it would mean installing GDAL. This issue would also apply to galah.
  • The taxize data structure is a combination of lists and dataframes. Not clear how this is better than a single dataframe, which captures all the tree information (see picture)

Options:

  • Add upstream and downstream functionality to select_taxa
  • Add vignette on how to get upstream and downstream information without special functions (i.e. use ala_species then loop through taxa to get intermediate information)
  • Keep select_taxa simple, and add more complicated functionality to taxize
